Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance. Additional amounts not required for scheduled payments are subject to Congressional approval. Additional amounts are to be allocated by the Secretary as specified. The Secretary is authorized to allocate additional amounts for capital infrastructure projects in various territories, subject to Congressional approval. For fiscal year 1996, funds are designated for American Samoa, while for fiscal years 1997 and beyond, projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, and other territories are eligible. Additionally, specific allocations are outlined for certain entities within these territories. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated for the College of the Northern Marianas. Up to $3 million annually can be used for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. Projects will be outlined in a five-year infrastructure plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, develops a five-year infrastructure plan outlining high-priority projects. The plan considers master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance needs, local cost-share requirements, and proposes an emergency fund of up to $2 million per year for disaster assistance. The cumulative amount for the emergency fund cannot exceed $10 million. Within the infrastructure allocations, additional funds can be provided for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, not exceeding $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995. These contributions must be used solely for resettlement activities and be properly audited. Federal agencies must ensure timely provision of these funds. The contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll are a final settlement of US obligations and must be used solely for resettlement activities. Federal agencies are authorized to provide funds for resettlement through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance may be provided for individuals not choosing to resettle at Rongelap, but only after all necessary funds for resettlement have been provided. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The minimum wage rates will start at $2.75 per hour, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996, and then raised annually by thirty cents or to match the federal minimum wage rate. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be equal to the wage rate set forth in section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act once it reaches that level. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, along with other government officials, must submit a report to Congress by March 15 each year detailing the use of funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the Commonwealth. The report includes immigration data, treatment of non-US citizen workers, foreign government interference, and the impact of CNMI laws on Federal interests. The report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior and other officials includes details on immigration data, treatment of non-US citizen workers, foreign government interference, CNMI laws' impact on Federal interests, detention facility adequacy, alien identification system reliability, and reasons for federal law enforcement challenges in the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within US waters. This amendment also updates references in the code accordingly. SEC. 6. Amends Public Law 93-435 to clarify ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. References to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands are updated in various sections. SEC. 7. Requires an annual State of the Islands report. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and administrative capabilities. Additionally, a technical correction is made to Public Law 95-134 regarding the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.
